info.game_comments:
Steve Chernicoff game 5.
Alex explains a new eligibility requirement for the Tournament of Champions.

(1, 1).clue: Jackson's heroic defense of this city came after the War of 1812 peace treaty had been signed

(2, 1).clue: This state is home to the muumuu

(3, 1).clue: In violin music martele means to accent the notes sharply, as if striking a nail with this tool

(4, 1).clue: One of these is considered dormant if it has erupted in historic times & is likely to again

(5, 1).clue: After her husband's murder in 1865, she became the 1st widow of a pres. to receive a yearly pension

(1, 2).clue: Jackson sat in the convention that framed this state's first constitution in 1796

(3, 2).clue: An instrumental composition that often features excerpts from ballets, like "The Nutcracker"

(4, 2).clue: These masses of snow that move rapidly down mountain slopes can reach speeds of over 200 MPH

(5, 2).clue: In 1932 Hattie Caraway from this "Land of Opportunity" became the 1st woman elected to the Senate

(1, 3).clue: This party held its first national nominating convention in 1832 to name Jackson's running mate

(2, 3).clue: A traditional sailor suit features trousers of this shape

(3, 3).clue: A symphonic poem such as Liszt's "Die Hunnenschlacht" is also known as this kind of "poem"

(4, 3).clue: This Rio de Janeiro landmark is an example of an inselberg or "island mountain"

(5, 3).clue: Harriet Quimby was the 1st woman to fly over this body of water, long before Gertrude Ederle swam it

(1, 4).clue: Jackson served in this war that began when he was 8 years old

(2, 4).clue: One may be harem, hobble or hoop

(3, 4).clue: It's the specific term for the person who writes the text of an opera

(4, 4).clue: The landmass is the part of the continental crust above this level

(5, 4).clue: Antonia Novello became the 1st woman surgeon general when she succeeded this man in 1990

(1, 5).clue: After his death in 1845, Jackson was buried in the garden of this plantation

(2, 5).clue: Color of a priest's alb, the linen robe worn for mass

(3, 5).clue: It's a fanciful or "humorous" French term for a composition; Dvorak wrote a famous one

(4, 5).clue: The oldest & largest division of geological time is the Pre-this

(5, 5).clue: Wounded during the Pearl Harbor attack, nurse Annie Fox was the 1st woman to receive this military medal

(1, 1).clue: Emi Koussi, an extinct volcano in Chad, is this desert's highest elevation

(2, 1).clue: In 1967 Sopwith Camel hit No. 26 with "Hello Hello" & this group hit No. 1 with "Hello, Goodbye"

(3, 1).clue: Geri & Freki are the 2 wolves who attend this greatest Norse god

(4, 1).clue: This comedian known for his bulbous nose & penchant for liquor died on Dec. 25, 1946

(5, 1).clue: The lowest recorded temperature in the U.S. was -79.8 degrees F. on Jan. 23, 1971, in this state

(6, 1).clue: Nicol Williamson's onstage antics made headlines when he played this Barrymore's ghost in "I Hate Hamlet"

(1, 2).clue: This country can be divided into 3 main regions: the Mountain Region, Tarai Region & Katmandu Valley

(2, 2).clue: The name of the secretary R.B. Greaves asked to "Take a Letter"

(3, 2).clue: In the legends of this country, a phoenix likes to roost in a woo-tung tree

(4, 2).clue: This invention of Fred Schmidt debuted at an American Bowling Congress tournament in Buffalo

(5, 2).clue: It's a measure of the amount of water vapor in the air

(6, 2).clue: A 1927 play by Eugene O'Neill deals with the life of this man after he's resurrected by Jesus

(1, 3).clue: The chief islands in this strategic gulf are Qishm & Bahrain

(2, 3).clue: Color of the curtains in Cream's "White Room"

(3, 3).clue: Ashur was the national god of this ancient Mesopotamian kingdom named for him

(4, 3).clue: In 1946 the Pope made Archbishop Spellman a cardinal & this American woman a saint

(5, 3).clue: One type of this instrument measures wind speed by using sound signals

(6, 3).clue: Tony Randall directed a 1992 revival of "The Master Builder" by this Scandinavian playwright

(1, 4).clue: This country's 2 largest lakes, Vanern & Vattern, are linked by the Gota Canal

(2, 4).clue: The colossal, colorful commercial character in the title of a 1965 Kingsmen hit

(3, 4).clue: Like his sister Cassandra, Helenus possessed the gift of this

(4, 4).clue: This German-turned-Swiss author of "Steppenwolf" picked up the Nobel Prize for Literature

(5, 4).clue: Averaging 25,000 feet & above, it's the highest standard cloud form

(6, 4).clue: This Italian form of improvised comedy featured tricks & stunts called lazzi

(1, 5).clue: Famed for its dancing & decorative arts, it's the most populous of Indonesia's Lesser Sunda Islands

(2, 5).clue: Featuring Reg Presley's ocarina playing, this was The Troggs' biggest U.S. hit

(3, 5).clue: This Roman goddess of wisdom wears a helmet because she's also the Roman goddess of war

(4, 5).clue: On Dec. 1, 1946 King Michael opened this country's new parliament

(5, 5).clue: This calm area near the equator is the meeting place for the northeast & southeast trade winds

(6, 5).clue: The first production of "The Sea Gull" failed, but it became a hit at this Russian theatre in 1898

(0, 0).clue: The novelist who wrote, "The beginning of the end of war lies in remembrance"
